Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I was just about to sit down for my evening prayers, the incense already lit and the soft glow of the lamp filling my room, when my phone buzzed urgently. It was Priya, my closest friend, her voice trembling. She was on her way to the airport and thought she’d left her passport at home. “Can you check and bring it to me? I’ll miss my flight otherwise,” she pleaded. My heart raced. As a friend, I knew she was counting on me, expecting me to drop everything and help her in this emergency. But as a Hindu, I felt the weight of my daily ritual, the quiet time I set aside to chant my mantras and find peace. I’d already skipped the full ritual today, whispering a few lines between tasks, and guilt gnawed at me. If I left now, I’d miss my only chance to complete my prayers properly. The expectations of both roles pressed in on me, and I stood frozen, torn between the urgent call of friendship and the quiet pull of my faith, unsure which path to take.
